awd_titl_txt: Archeomagnetism of Southern Africa: Implications for Longevity of the South Atlantic Anomaly
awd_abstract_narration:
A broad low intensity area in Earth's recent magnetic field spans the southern Atlantic Ocean, Africa and South America. This is commonly called the South Atlantic Anomaly (SAA). The SAA allows a relatively close approach of Earth's radiation belts, affecting spacecraft operations. The low magnetic intensity decreases the efficiency of magnetic shielding in the region, which can influence atmospheric ozone. Many believe the SAA is linked to the dramatic decay of the dipole geomagnetic field intensity during the last 160 years, and the growth of an area of reversed magnetic field on Earth's core beneath South Africa. Some have even speculated Earth is heading toward a geomagnetic field reversal. But understanding these phenomena within the context of longer-term geomagnetic history has been limited by a lack of Southern Hemisphere archeomagnetic data (that is, data from archeological objects that were fired to high temperature and subsequently preserved a record of Earth's magnetic field as they cooled). Our research and education program is aimed at understanding the history of the geomagnetic field in the SAA region as recorded in southern Africa. The main focus of the work is the collection and subsequent analysis of archeomagnetic data from Iron Age burnt structures, and tests of models addressing how the nature of the boundary between Earth's core and mantle may be giving rise to recent changes seen in the geomagnetic field.


Archeomagnetic data from Iron Age sites of southern Africa (ca. 1000-1650 AD) show a sharp intensity drop at 1300 AD, at a rate comparable to modern field changes in the present-day South Atlantic Anomaly (SAA), but to lower values. The recurrence of low field values may reflect magnetic flux expulsion from the core promoted by the unusual core-mantle boundary composition and structure beneath southern Africa defined by seismology (specifically the African Large Low Velocity Seismic Province, or LLVSP). Because the African LLVSP is a longstanding structure, this region might be a steady site of flux expulsion, and perhaps the triggering site for geomagnetic reversals, on time scales of millions of years.  If correct, this conceptual model is transformative because it suggests reversals do not initiate at random locations, but instead nucleate at core-mantle boundary sites that promote flux to leak upward. The model predicts modulation of the field on time scales of the lifetime of an eddy in the core flow, and will be tested by extending the archeomagnetic record of Iron Age southern Africa. The research program is integrated with undergraduate and graduate education and will be conducted with geologists and archeologists from South Africa, Botswana, and Zimbabwe.  This project was co-funded by the GVF fund in the Office of International Science Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The dominant part of Earth's magnetic field - known as the dipole - is rapidly weakening and this decay has societal implications. The magnetic field shields Earth from harmful cosmic radiation, especially the charged particles that compose the solar wind that constantly streams from the Sun. The magnetic field decrease appears concentrated in an area of the Southern Hemisphere spanning South Africa to Chile known as the South Atlantic Anomaly. If the decrease in field strength continues over many decades to centuries, this shielding could become less effective. Effects on the atmospheric, including minor ozone depletion, could begin to emerge. Satellites and Earth's infrastructure might become even more vulnerable to damage caused by very large solar events (known as coronal mass ejections). Anything we can learn about the historical context of the recent dipole decay could lead to a better understanding of future changes.

We proposed a conceptual model (Tarduno et al., Nature Communications, 2015) whereby the recent dipole decay is the latest manifestation of a recurrent phenomenon in the outer core where the magnetic field is generated. The composition and structure of the lowermost mantle beneath southern Africa (defined by seismology) is unusual and has the potential to cause perturbations in the flow of the underlying liquid iron core. These perturbations might further lead to an anomaly in the magnetic field. Because the lowermost mantle structure beneath southern Africa is truly ancient (at least tens-of-millions of years old) it may have a long-term influence on the magnetic field. The magnetic anomalies generated might have even triggered some past magnetic pole reversals. If correct, this model is transformative because it suggests pole reversals do not initiate at random locations, but instead nucleate at special places in the outer core. A discussion of the decay of the geomagnetic field and this model can be found in The Conversation (Does an anomaly in Earth's magnetic field portend a coming pole reversal? J. Tarduno and V. Hare, 2017).

The major goal on the project was to test this model through extending and refining the geomagnetic record from southern Africa through the analysis of archeologic sites. The work involves an international collaboration, with colleagues (geologists, geophysicists and archeologists) from South Africa, Botswana, and Zimbabwe. The work supported graduate students and undergraduates who acquired valuable skills though training in the field and in the laboratory.

We were able to generate a record of the geomagnetic field for Iron Age southern Africa (approximately 425 CE to present). The reference data support our hypothesis and provide evidence for older geomagnetic anomalies. These reference data are in turn useful for constraining ages of undated Iron Age sites and thus could assist in future archeological studies, including those relating paleoclimate and culture in the Limpopo River region. Finally, we note our model predicts that geomagnetic anomalies originating beneath South Africa drift with the flow of iron in the outer core and appear a few hundred years later beneath South America. New data from South America generated by other groups provide evidence for geomagnetic anomalies predicted by our model. These observations provide motivation for future investigations to learn more about the processes shaping the past, present and future geomagnetic field.
